title: 112_hr601
content: The Act titled "End Big Oil Tax Subsidies Act of 2011" aims to amortize geological and geophysical expenditures. The Act "End Big Oil Tax Subsidies Act of 2011" is amending the Internal Revenue Code to replace "major integrated oil company" with "covered large oil company" and defining the latter as a taxpayer with gross receipts exceeding $50,000,000 for the taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to amounts paid or incurred in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude taxpayers who are not small, independent oil and gas companies from certain provisions. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. SEC. 4 introduces an enhanced oil recovery credit for small, independent oil and gas companies. It excludes taxpayers who are not small, independent oil and gas companies. The effective date for this amendment is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 5 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude certain oil and gas companies from intangible drilling and development cost deductions. It applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. SEC. 6 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exempt non-small, independent oil and gas companies from percentage depletion deductions. It applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. The amendment to Section 193 of the Internal Revenue Code exempts non-small, independent oil and gas companies from certain tax provisions. This exemption includes expenses related to qualified carbon dioxide disposed in secure geological storage. The amendment treats persons as a single employer and applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2011. SEC. 8 amends section 469(c) of the Internal Revenue Code to exempt taxpayers who are not small, independent oil and gas companies from certain passive activity loss rules. SEC. 9 relates to income from domestic production activities. SEC. 9 amends Section 199 of the Internal Revenue Code to exclude income from oil and gas production for non-small, independent companies. The amendment is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to restrict major integrated oil companies from using a specific inventory method. This change applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011, requiring affected taxpayers to adjust their accounting method accordingly. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to restrict major integrated oil companies from using a specific inventory method. Taxpayers must adjust their accounting method with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury and spread the adjustments over a period not exceeding 8 taxable years. SEC. 11. Modifications of foreign tax credit rules for dual capacity taxpayers. SEC. 11. Modifications of foreign tax credit rules for dual capacity taxpayers. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include special rules for dual capacity taxpayers regarding foreign oil and gas income. Amounts paid exceeding the required tax are not considered a tax for dual capacity taxpayers. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States, who receives a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. These amendments apply to taxes paid or accrued after December 31, 2011, except where contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States.
